Final Results

  • nmap-7.91/libpcap/lbl/os-sunos4.h:129: [5] (race) readlink: This accepts filename arguments; if an attacker can move those files or change the link content, a race condition results. Also, it does not terminate with ASCII NUL. (CWE-362, CWE-20). Reconsider approach.
  • nmap-7.91/libpcap/pcap-linux.c:607: [5] (race) readlink: This accepts filename arguments; if an attacker can move those files or change the link content, a race condition results. Also, it does not terminate with ASCII NUL. (CWE-362, CWE-20). Reconsider approach.
  • nmap-7.91/libz/contrib/untgz/untgz.c:32: [5] (race) chmod: This accepts filename arguments; if an attacker can move those files, a race condition results. (CWE-362). Use fchmod( ) instead.
  • nmap-7.91/libz/contrib/untgz/untgz.c:277: [5] (race) chmod: This accepts filename arguments; if an attacker can move those files, a race condition results. (CWE-362). Use fchmod( ) instead.
  • nmap-7.91/nbase/nbase_misc.c:764: [5] (race) readlink: This accepts filename arguments; if an attacker can move those files or change the link content, a race condition results. Also, it does not terminate with ASCII NUL. (CWE-362, CWE-20). Reconsider approach.
  • nmap-7.91/nping/ProbeMode.cc:1684: [5] (buffer) strncat: Easily used incorrectly (e.g., incorrectly computing the correct maximum size to add) [MS-banned] (CWE-120). Consider strcat_s, strlcat, snprintf, or automatically resizing strings. Risk is high; the length parameter appears to be a constant, instead of computing the number of characters left.
  • nmap-7.91/nping/ProbeMode.cc:1712: [5] (buffer) strncat: Easily used incorrectly (e.g., incorrectly computing the correct maximum size to add) [MS-banned] (CWE-120). Consider strcat_s, strlcat, snprintf, or automatically resizing strings. Risk is high; the length parameter appears to be a constant, instead of computing the number of characters left.
  • nmap-7.91/NmapOutputTable.h:106: [4] (format) printf: If format strings can be influenced by an attacker, they can be exploited (CWE-134). Use a constant for the format specification.
  • nmap-7.91/libdnet-stripped/include/dnet_winconfig.h:280: [4] (format) snprintf: If format strings can be influenced by an attacker, they can be exploited, and note that sprintf variations do not always \0-terminate (CWE-134). Use a constant for the format specification.
  • nmap-7.91/libdnet-stripped/include/dnet_winconfig.h:280: [4] (format) _snprintf: If format strings can be influenced by an attacker, they can be exploited, and note that sprintf variations do not always \0-terminate (CWE-134). Use a constant for the format specification.
  • nmap-7.91/libdnet-stripped/src/arp-ioctl.c:221: [4] (buffer) sscanf: The scanf() family's %s operation, without a limit specification, permits buffer overflows (CWE-120, CWE-20). Specify a limit to %s, or use a different input function.

  • nmap-7.91/libpcap/lbl/os-sunos4.h:92: [4] (misc) getpass: This function is obsolete and not portable. It was in SUSv2 but removed by POSIX.2. What it does exactly varies considerably between systems, particularly in where its prompt is displayed and where it gets its data (e.g., /dev/tty, stdin, stderr, etc.). In addition, some implementations overflow buffers. (CWE-676, CWE-120, CWE-20). Make the specific calls to do exactly what you want. If you continue to use it, or write your own, be sure to zero the password as soon as possible to avoid leaving the cleartext password visible in the process' address space.

Consider using strcat_s, strncat, strlcat, or snprintf (warning: strncat is easily misused). Risk is low because the source is a constant character.
